Recovering my Past with a Toothbrush and a Broken 1990’s Apple Mac

Notes from my younger self

Jeremy Sutton, PhD
Apr 2
I turned on the power and was greeted with the same vertical stripes on the screen. Had I expected it to be different, to have fixed itself?

The student

I bought this iconic Apple Macintosh Classic II computer in 1992, during my first year at university. I still remember the excitement of picking the box up, getting it home, unpacking, powering it up, and hearing the startup chime. At the time, it felt cutting-edge. It had a mouse, icons, and windows that could be stretched, or dragged, around the screen. It was portable — unusual then — in as much as it had a carry handle built in.

Using the Apple Mac, I felt academic and empowered. It was intelligent, refined, studious, and quite possibly, out of my league.

The Mac and I, survived many late nights together: last-minute essays, coding, statistics, experiments, and dissertations. Through the 3 years of my Cognitive Science degree, and 2 years of my Philosophy MA, we witnessed the highs and lows of academia, student life and relationships. This silent, but watchful, companion sat in the corner of my students digs throughout.

Since then, 1997, it had been forgotten, like a discarded friend.

It was boxed and stored at my Mum’s house, and the years passed…

The Adult

Now in my 40’s, I was married with children and living in Northern Ireland, a long way from my student days in Hertfordshire. Memories of my 20’s had receded in the distance. But, I was a student again, now working towards a PhD (see my earlier post), part-time, in Human Endurance - exploring the psychology and physiology of ultra-marathoners. I had been inspired by a healthier lifestyle that the younger me could not have foreseen.

Last year, whilst my family and I were back home for a week beside the beach, I happened across a bruised and worn cardboard box. With a hint of academic nostalgia, I unboxed the machine, plugged the mouse into the keyboard, the keyboard into the computer, and then the plug into the mains. An expectant flick of the power switch, a whirr, and … disappointment.

There was no smiling face as I powered up, instead, rather disappointingly multiple white stripes on a grey background — like a test card late at night, after the TV had finished. Back in the day when there was a time at night when the TV did actually finish.

I left it for a while to perhaps cool down, to mend itself miraculously. However, it still didn’t work when I tried it again later.

Perhaps I had become sentimental, but I wanted to see the earlier me, from across the academic and technical divide.

According to YouTube, the fount (or font) of all knowledge, this was a common fault. Apparently the capacitors on old Apple Mac’s leaked, over the decades, and caused a boot failure. The solution, though unlikely, was to take the casing off, disconnect all internal leads, remove the logic board, then soak and gently scrub, in warm, soapy water with an old toothbrush.

Water and electronics rarely mix well, as some of my earlier iPhones can testify, but I had nothing to lose.

Once scrubbed, I let the board dry for 3 days….

I then slotted the board back in, reattached the cabling and put the casing back on, before slotting the mouse and keyboard plugs in.

I took a deep breath and hesitantly turned the power switch on at the back. I was expecting a loud bang, but instead was rewarded with a bing and a smiling icon, a lot of whirring and the startup was a success. The screen opened with a half-finished chess game and a story I had stopped writing part-way through, 22 years ago, to which I was to never return.

I felt like this was a homecoming — a technological one at least — like returning to an academic Marie Celeste.

Revisiting the past

Over the coming days I stepped in and out of my past, reading through my study, and personal, notes, and homework from multiple disciplines: psychology, linguistics, logic, programming, neuroscience, and philosophy. It was a younger me that spoke — I could hear the voice when I read — but it was me. Perhaps more naive, definitely less complicated, a mixture of angst, optimism and searching…

I explored..

I wrote my degree thesis on computational linguistics. My writing highlighted methods of natural language processing, ‘rule-based’ versus ‘data-driven’, and discussed the ability of human and artificial processing to produce and comprehend language. The debate then, as now, raged over nature versus nature: was language innate?

My views have not really changed. After all, some innate knowledge seems inevitable: psychological adaptations and mechanisms resulting from 2 million years of evolution; surviving and thriving, in small and large social groups. Chomsky’s theories of Universal Grammar, and Transformational Generative Grammar, along with Steven Pinker’s ‘Language of Thought’, were paid considerable attention and are even still well worth re-visiting. Indeed, my current role involves working with voice biometrics to ensure an automated understanding of a customer’s speech when they phone a bank. There remain questions outstanding regarding the very nature of true understanding, possibly linked to consciousness:

Is it enough to say that if a human or computer behaves as if they ‘understand’ a sentence, that they be said to be linguistically competent? (me, 1994)

The level of competence a device has when it appears to comprehend a request, or instruction (Siri, Alexa, etc), can still be said to be minimal, in a cognitive sense. But these boundaries will become less clear over the coming years of technological advancement.

For a developer to design a computer system to both understand and produce natural language (whether written or verbal) he, or she, must first make the decision to either: (1) supply grammatical rules at the outset, (2) let the system ‘find’ its own rules, or (3) create a solution that combines the two approaches. (me, 1994)

Alexa, the voice-activated interface/assistant relies on, and learns from, a large and growing body of data, to give the impression of competence, along with a set of rules beneath. Technology appears to have chosen option 3.

My fiction, both prose, and poetry, was clearly influenced by the poetry of Rimbaud, Blake and Baudelaire; the philosophy of Sartre, Nietzsche and Camus; the fiction of Douglas Coupland (Generation X) and Hermann Hesse, and drawn, like a moth to the flame, to the words of Jim Morrison, and the music of The Doors.

I found an island in your arms, country in your eyes,
Arms that chain, eyes that lie,
Break on through to the other side,
Break on through to the other side.
(Break on Through, The Doors)

Re-reading my past thoughts, I see a soul searching to understand: love, the mind, death, and both the edges and the theatre of life.

In the garden of the dreamers, all the plants bear fruit…
In eternity there are no guarantees, ride the good times, like a kite hangs on the breeze…
(from various pieces, me, 1992–95)

I still love the existentialist philosophers: Camus and Sartre. Their work is more relevant than ever, if only for their recognition of the absurdity of life, and humanity’s angst resulting from being condemned to freedom. But also the pragmatism of Nietzsche, philosophising with a hammer.

Nowadays my only poetry is to be found in the flow of running, somehow reading it seems lacking in practicality: my loss, and a sign of trying to get too much done, in too little time.

My Philosophy thesis was titled the ‘Relevance of Existentialism Today’. Two things stand out when I read it now. Firstly, the central problems of being remain the same: I cannot imagine a person living, or dead, who hasn’t had doubts or concerns over the very nature of living. What is the point of being? What is the nature of our existence?

Over the last 20 years, I listened to, and often failed to take, the advice contained within these pages:

  • Take life personally
  • Live authentically

Sartre and Nietzsche both push for the individual to become more than they are. In ‘Thus Spoke Zarathustra’, Nietzsche goads the reader with the following:

One repays a teacher badly if one always remains nothing but the pupil.

A final quote in the dissertation provides the best advice. Taken from Herman Hesse’s ‘Steppenwolf’, which to this day remains my favourite book:

You have got to learn to laugh. That will be required of you. You must apprehend the humour of life, its gallows-humour.

Over 20 years later, what does this mean?

More will surface from this digital treasure trove, but there is no rush, there is enough to ruminate on for the moment.

I’ve had a glimpse into the earlier me, and this has satisfied my curiosity.

In some ways, everything, and in many ways nothing, has changed.

Like the Ship of Theseus: each year, new planks replace the old, eventually, nothing original from the ship is left. The ship looks mostly the same, but is not, and yet functions as it did before. Am I still the man who typed on the recovered Apple Mac? Or is my being, and identity, inherently linked to the time I find myself in?

Life has happened — the highs, lows, happy and sad times — but I still recognise myself in this other pre-wifi, digital me.
